# (Ford GoBike System Data 2017)
## by (Sarah Alazeri)

## Preliminary Wrangling

> This data set includes information about individual rides made in a bike-sharing system covering the greater San Francisco Bay area.

# import all packages and set plots to be embedded inline
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sb

%matplotlib inline
> Load the dataset ( for year 2017 ) and describe its properties:

source: fordgobike.head(1)

# Change the dtypes.
fordgobike.start_time = pd.to_datetime(fordgobike.start_time)
fordgobike.end_time = pd.to_datetime(fordgobike.end_time)

fordgobike.bike_id = fordgobike.bike_id.astype(str)
fordgobike.user_type = fordgobike.user_type.astype('category')

# add some needed columns .
fordgobike['hour'] = fordgobike.start_time.dt.strftime('%H')
fordgobike['day'] = fordgobike.start_time.dt.strftime('%a')
fordgobike['month'] = fordgobike.start_time.dt.strftime('%b')

### What is the structure of your dataset?

> we have 519700 rows and 13 columns.

### What is/are the main feature(s) of interest in your dataset?

> 
- Duration time for each trip
- Type of users


### What features in the dataset do you think will help support your investigation into your feature(s) of interest?

> There are many features in the dataset can support my investigation :
- duration_sec
- start_time
- end_time
- user_type

## Univariate Exploration

> In this section, investigate distributions of individual variables. If
you see unusual points or outliers, take a deeper look to clean things up
and prepare yourself to look at relationships between variables.

# find the disribution for trip durations
binedges = np.arange(0, fordgobike['duration_sec'].max() + 100 ,100)
plt.hist(data = fordgobike, x = 'duration_sec', bins=binedges)
plt.xlim(0,6000)
plt.title('Distribution of various Trip Duration')
plt.xlabel('Duration in Seconds')
plt.ylabel('Frequency');
- Form this plot  we can say that most of the duration between 400-600.

# Find the highest classification of user type .
sorted_counts = fordgobike['user_type'].value_counts()
plt.pie(sorted_counts, labels = sorted_counts.index, startangle = 90,counterclock = False,autopct='%.2f%%');
plt.axis('square')
plt.title('Distribution of User type',size=15)
plt.show()
- As we can see that 78% of our trips in the datast is by Subscriber user type which is most popular than Customer .

# Find the highest trip day .
sb.countplot(data = fordgobike, x = 'day', color = 'orange')
sb.set(font_scale=0.90)
plt.title('Distribution day',size=15)
plt.xlabel('Days',size=13)
plt.ylabel('Count',size=13);
- From this bar chart, we can see that the highest trip day is Tuesday and wednesday , the lowest day is Sunday.

### Discuss the distribution(s) of your variable(s) of interest. Were there any unusual points? Did you need to perform any transformations?

>- We can see from the charts above that i used a distribuation of trip duration and distribuation of user type and distribuation of day,  i dont think that it has any unusual points. 

### Of the features you investigated, were there any unusual distributions? Did you perform any operations on the data to tidy, adjust, or change the form of the data? If so, why did you do this?

>- The data is tidy , All of values are correct and do not need any extra operations.

## Bivariate Exploration

> In this section, investigate relationships between pairs of variables in your
data. Make sure the variables that you cover here have been introduced in some
fashion in the previous section (univariate exploration).

#Find the relationship between user type and week days.
plo= sb.countplot(data = fordgobike, x = 'day', hue = 'user_type')
plo.legend(loc = 8, ncol = 3, framealpha = 50)
plt.title('The relationship between user type and weekdays ',size=13)
plt.xlabel('Days',size=11)
plt.ylabel('Num of trips',size=11);
- From this bar chart we can see that There is a huge difference between Customer type and Subscriber type but in Saturday and Sunday the different between them is less than the rest of the weak.

#Find the Relationship between duration and user type .
plt.figure(figsize = [8,6])
sb.barplot(data = fordgobike, x = 'user_type', y = 'duration_sec', palette = 'Oranges')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)

plt.title('Relationship between duration and user type');
plt.show()
- From this plot we see the Customer type has longest duration than Subscriber.

# Find the relationship between trip duration and months.
plt.figure(figsize = [8,8])
plot= sb.barplot(data=fordgobike,x='month',y='duration_sec', ci=None)
plt.xlabel('Months')
plt.ylabel('Trip Duration')
plt.title('Trip Duration vs Months');
- As we can see that users prefer using the bikes on july and august more than other months .

### Talk about some of the relationships you observed in this part of the investigation. How did the feature(s) of interest vary with other features in the dataset?

> 
- I have seen The relationship between user type and weekdays.
- I have seen The trip duration for the customer type is higher than the subscriber type.
- I have seen that on july and august users prefer using the bikes for longer trips.

### Did you observe any interesting relationships between the other features (not the main feature(s) of interest)?

> I have seen that the relationship between trip duration and months was interesting because it is show that users prefer using the bikes on summer months .

## Multivariate Exploration

> Create plots of three or more variables to investigate your data even
further. Make sure that your investigations are justified, and follow from
your work in the previous sections.

fig = plt.figure(figsize = [8,6])
sb.pointplot(data = fordgobike, x = 'day', y = 'duration_sec', hue = 'user_type', palette = 'Greens', ci=None)

plt.title('Trip duartion across user type in different days')
plt.ylabel('Mean Trip Dduration in SEC')
plt.xlabel('Days')
plt.show();
- As we said before the customer type has the longer trips duration especially in the sunday but the subscriber it is so low and the most highest duration in saturday.
- From this figure we can see that the durtion of trips that started at 3 am it is higher.
- We can see that customers oftenly using the bike much longer duration than the subscribers , also  customers prefer using it on july .

### Talk about some of the relationships you observed in this part of the investigation. Were there features that strengthened each other in terms of looking at your feature(s) of interest?

> 
- I have seen the relationship between months and user_type against Trip duration.

### Were there any interesting or surprising interactions between features?

> 
- In the last figure, we find "july" As the preferred month for customers.
